chunks.en: I got a 500M telecom broadband this weekend. The optical modem is in the living room, about 5m away from my room with two walls in between. The 2.4G wifi can connect, but the network speed is very poor. It lags even when watching videos, and the 5G wifi cannot connect at all.
Now I want to buy a gigabit router. I looked at the ZTE Xuntian be5100, ZTE Xuntian be5100pro+, and ZTE Xuntian ax3000pro+.
I don't know if buying the ZTE Xuntian be5100 is enough. Comments say its wall-penetration ability is average.
Spending money on a router is not as effective as running a network cable or using invisible fiber.
I bought the ZTE Xuntian AX3000Pro+ to replace my old Netgear RAX80; the experience is very good, there are no disconnections or lags, and the 5G is very stable throughout the house.
@hangzhou #2 Are you renting a room? Then run a flat network cable along the skirting board of the living room all the way to the bedroom. As long as you get it to the bedroom, any router will do.
Previously, it was tested that the network speed of a TP router worth hundreds of RMB dropped sharply and the latency was huge when penetrating two walls (load-bearing walls).
@wxw752 I don't understand this. The person who installed the broadband told me to get a router. I'll go check it out.
If you don't have high requirements for latency, you can try the mesh routers on the market.

chunks.en: Wireless is a two-way connection. It's not just about the AP's transmission power being strong; the AP also needs to be able to receive the signal sent back by the terminal.

I never have any requirements for network speed...even a 100mbps telecom broadband is very easy to use. So if there is a network cable in the room, installing it directly in the room is the right solution.

As for whether the equipment is sufficient, it depends on the needs of different people. A 100mbps external network is enough for me to play games/watch TV. The equipment is an old tp wdr 4310 flashed with openwrt.
The effect of a single router through two walls is probably not very good. You still need to get two routers and set up a mesh.
I bought the ZTE Xuntian be5100pro+. The background management is really rubbish, and I have basically never seen a firmware update, but the signal is okay.
5 meters away, 5100 is not enough at all.
It's best to run a network cable over and then connect a router.
If not, you can buy two small routers like ax3000 and set up a mesh.
The signal of TP's xdr5480 is actually not bad in the newly built house in my hometown. I bought it on pdd for more than 300.

chunks.en: I think that if possible, Wi-Fi should not be used through walls. Use the router itself or a wireless router with DHCP turned off to connect to the LAN port to cover frequently used areas; this will better guarantee speed, signal, and mobile device battery life.

chunks.en: Specifically for the OP's situation, you can run a network cable from the living room to the room where you use the internet, and then buy a wireless router that supports Wi-Fi 6 (axXXXX), turn off DHCP in the settings, and then connect the network cable to any LAN port.

In this way, the new router can supplement the coverage of areas that the optical modem's Wi-Fi cannot cover, but unless the price difference is not significant, there is no need to buy Wi-Fi 7 (beXXXX) routers at this stage, as mobile devices have not yet become popular.
A single router can't handle it. For high-quality internet access, you need to add another router in your bedroom.
I use ZTE Qingtian + Xuntian. Although ZTE's hardware configuration is low and cannot be flashed, it is stable.
The wifi signal of the optical modem itself is indeed not very good. If there is a pre-laid network cable, you can get a cheap router.
If you don't want to bother, just replace the router.
